pypospack.io.ase.transform_cartesian_to_direct(v, lattice)[source]¶

transformation of cartesian coordinates to direct coordinates

If the lattice is an H vector, with the rows being the lattice vectors, the if r is a column vector of the director coordinates of H, and x is the Cartesian coordinates, then x = H.T r.

Parameters

  • v (list) – a list of floats representing the coordinates in the cartesian basis.

  • lattice (list) – a list of lists representing the lattice in H-matrix form

Returns

a list of float representing the coordinates in the lattice vector.

Return type

list

pypospack.io.eamtools module¶

class pypospack.io.eamtools.EamFuncflFile[source]¶

Bases: object

class pypospack.io.eamtools.EamSetflFile[source]¶

Bases: object

This class wites a setfl file.

There are three components to the EAM model: the embedding energy, the electron density, and interatomic pair potential. LAMMPS uses a very old format for reading/writing EAM files.

The potential functions are stored as they would be generated from their functional forms, in units eV. However, they are written to be compliant with the setfl format which requires the element to be stored as V(r)*r.

Both the electron density function and the potential energy has a physical requirement that V(r_cut) = 0 and rho(r_cut) = 0. The application of a cutoff function not implemented by this class, and it is responsibility of the code using this class to ensure this.

All units of measurement are in metal units. Distance being Angstroms, and energy being eV.

Parameters

None –

comments¶

The setfl file format has a three line comment section at the beginning of the file.

Type

list of str

filename¶

This is the filename to either read/write too.

Type

str

symbols¶

This is a list of symbols modelled by the Embedded Atom Model.

Type

list of str

n_symbols¶

This is the number of elements for the setfl file.

Type

int

N_r¶

The number of points sampled for the distance from the nuclei in the electron density function, or the distance between two atoms in pair potentials.

Type

int

N_rho¶

The number of points where the electron density is sampled.

Type

int

d_r¶

Distance between the point where the potential functions and the electron density function are evaluated.

Type

float

d_rho¶

Distance between the points where the delectron density is sampled.

Type

float

r¶

This is a :numpy.ndarray: array of possible evaluations from d_r to r_max with N_r intervals. It does not include r = 0.

Type

numpy.ndarray

rho¶

This is an :numpy.ndarray: array of possible evaluations from d_rho to rho_max with N_rho interals. It does not include rho = 0.

Type

numpy.ndarray

func_embedding¶

This is a dictionary containing the embedding function. The embedding function is indexed by elements in the symbols attribute. The embedding function is stored as an :numpy.ndarray: of length N_r. This attribute is initialized as None.

Type

OrderedDict

func_density¶

This is a dictionary containing the electron density function indexed by elements in the symbols attribute. The density function is stored as an :numpy.ndarray: of length N_r. This attribute is initialized as None.

Type

OrderedDict

func_pair_potential¶

They has the format ‘sym_i.sym_j’ which are generated from unique combinations from the symbols attribute. The pairs are selected as s_i, s_j in S, where i <= j. This attribute is initialized as none.

Type

OrderedDict

Ref:

https://sites.google.com/a/ncsu.edu/cjobrien/tutorials-and-guides/eam http://www.ctcms.nist.gov/potentials/ http://lammps.sandia.gov/doc/pair_eam.html

N_r
N_rho

process_setfl_header_section()[source]¶

Process the header section of the setfl file.

The header section consists of two sections

process_setfl_n_symbols()[source]¶
process_setfl_pairpotential_section()[source]¶

The SETFL convention for storing V(r) is as r*V(r). This was probably important during the time when computational cycles were expensive. However, we divide this storage value by r to get the potential in eV.

class pypospack.io.filesystem.OrderedDictYAMLLoader(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: yaml.loader.Loader

A YAML loader that loads mappings into ordered dictionaries.

Use: >>> import yaml >>> from pypospack.io.filesystem import OrderedDictYAMLLoader >>> with open(filename,’r’) as f: >>> data = yaml.load(f,OrderedDictYAMLLoader)

Source:

Original code for the YAML loader. Eric Naeseth. https://gist.github.com/enaeseth/844388

pypospack.io.phonts module¶

pypospack.io.phonts

This module provides input and output routines and classes for managing simulations for Phonon Transport Simulation (PhonTS), written by A. Chernatiynskiy and S.R. Phillpot. PhonTS is a lattice dynamics code that calculates thermal conductivity via the solution of the Boltzmann Transport Equation (BTE) for phonons.

This module’s purpose is to automate the work required to interface PhonTS to other codes such as LAMMPS for additional potentials, and first principals electronic structure calculations (VASP). While an interface is defined for Quantum Expresso QE) for PhonTS, this interface is not implemented with pypospack.io.phonts.

For a more a more in-depth understand of the PhonTS refer to the foundation papers:

A. Chernatiynskiy and S.R. Phillpot, PRB 82, 134301 (2010) A. Chernatiynskiy and S.R. Phillpot, Comp. Phys. Comm. (2015)

This module does not implement all the functionality which is available in PhonTS.

Requirements¶

The use of this module requires setting the enviornment variable the .bash_profile or similar script on your system

export PHONTS_BIN=~/bin/PhonTS

Job Schedulers¶

Due to the wide variety and implementations of the cluster job schedulers, it is not possible to write all the possibilities of the job scheduler. The general strategy for dealing with job submissions is to create a

pypospack.io.slurm pypospack.io.rocks pypospack.io.pbs

  • phonon_kpoints (list of int) – K-point mesh in on which phonon properties are to be calculated. It should be an array with four elements, [N1,N2,N3,N4], where N4 specifies the finer grid along the z-axis for more accurate determination of the energy conversation surface in thermal conductivity simulations.

pypospack.io.phonts.phonts_bte_section()[source]¶
pypospack.io.phonts.phonts_dispersions()[source]¶
pypospack.io.phonts.phonts_kpoints_section_to_str(k1=9, k2=9, k3=9, kbte=1)[source]¶

Define the kpoint mesh for Phonons

Defines the k-point mesh on which phonon properties are to be calculated. kx, ky, and kz determine resolutions in the reciprocal space. PhonTS automatically create an odd-valued grid, even if an even-grid is provided.

Parameters

  • kx (int) – kpoint mesh resolution in the b1 direction, reciprocal lattice

  • ky (int) – kpoint mesh resolution in thee b2 direction, reciprocal lattice

  • kz (int) – kpoint mesh resolution in the b3 direction, reciprocal lattice

  • kbte (int) – additional resolution for the finer grid in the z direction, for more accurate determination of the energy conservation surface in thermal conductivity calculations.

pypospack.io.phonts.read_phon_lifetime(filename='phon_lifetime.dat')[source]¶

Reads phonon lifetime information

pypospack.io.phonts.simulation_cell_to_phonts_string(simulation_cell, charges=None)[source]¶

This function converts as simulation cell and a dictionary of charges into the simulation cell secton of the PhonTS input file.

Parameters

  • simulation_cell (pypospack.crystal.SimulationCell) – This arguement expects the simulation cell to either to be a SimulationCell object, or an object which inherits those methods.

  • charges (OrderedDict) – This keys of this dictionary should have the ISO chemical symbols of the atoms while the values of these keys should provide floats of the charge.

Returns

a string of the the simulation cell in PhonTS format.

Return type

(str)

class pypospack.io.vasp.Kpoints(filename='KPOINTS', comment='Automatic Mesh', n_kpoints=0, mesh_type='Monkhorst-Pack', mesh_size=[4, 4, 4], mesh_shift=[0, 0, 0])[source]¶

Bases: object

KPOINTS file

Parameters

  • filename (str) – the filename to either read from or to write to. Default is KPOINTS

  • comment (str) – a comment to use for the KPOINTS file. Default is ‘Automatic Mesh’

  • n_kpoints (int) – number of kpoints for automatic mesh. Default is 0.

  • mesh_type (str) – mesh type to create. Default is ‘Monkhorst-Pack’

  • mesh_size (list of int) – defines the density of the sampling in the Brillouin zone of the reciprocal lattice.

  • mesh_shift (list of int) – defines the shift of the k-kpoint mesh

class pypospack.io.vasp.Outcar(filename='OUTCAR')[source]¶

Bases: object

object to manage IO to VASP through the OUTCAR file

Many of the attributes in this class are initialized to None at instanciation. They are processed when the OUTCAR file is read.

Parameters

filename (str) – filename of the OUTCAR file

total_energy¶

total energy of the structure in eV.

Type

float

elastic_tensor¶

the components of the elastic tensor. The components of the array start at . So the component would be accessed by elastic_tensor[0,0]

Type

nd.array

phonon_eig_val¶

the eigenvalues of the phonons determined by lattice dynamics.

Type

nd.array

phonon_eig_vec¶

the eigenvectors of the phonons determined by lattice dynamics.

Type

nd.array

class pypospack.io.vasp.Potcar(symbols=None, filename=None, xc='GGA', potcars=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

object to deal with POTCAR files for VASP simulations

Parameters

  • symbols (list of str) – a list of chemical symbols

  • filename (str) – the filename of the POTCAR

  • xc (str) – the exchange correlation model. Default is ‘GGA’

potcar_dir¶

the path of the VASP potential directory.

Type

str

potcars¶

a dictionary of key-value pairs of symbols to potcar type where the key value is the ISO symbol, and the value is the the psuedopotnetial type.

Type

dict

If an str is passed into symbols, then the string will be cast into a list of str

A directory of potentials is not included in pypospack because it is protected by copy right. If the potcar_dir is not set, then pypospack will use the environment variables:

>>> export VASP_LDA_DIR=$(cd ~/opt/vasp/potentials/LDA;pwd)
>>> export VASP_GGA_DIR=$(cd ~/opt/vasp/potentials/GGA;pwd)
